titleStmt.title: Description of University of Pennsylvania Ms. Codex 131: Italian alchemical miscellany

availability.licence: These images and the content of Kislak Center for Special Collections, Rare Books and Manuscripts Ms. Codex 131: Italian alchemical miscellany are free of known copyright restrictions and in the public domain. See the Creative Commons Public Domain Mark page for usage details, http://creativecommons.org/publicdomain/mark/1.0/.

notesStmt.note: The incipits of the first (Verum est sine mendatio..., f. 3r) and fourth (Recipe limatura lupi limati libram unam...) works are listed in Thorndike and Kibre, Catalogue of Incipits of Mediaeval Scientific Writings in Latin.

msIdentifier.repository: Kislak Center for Special Collections, Rare Books and Manuscripts

msContents.summary: Collection of alchemical recipes preceded by a few brief treatises (including a commentary attributed to Hortulanus and a work referring to Arnaldus de Villanova). Folios 1-2, 40 and 42-43 are blank. There is a short guide, index or key in a later hand at the end (f. 41r).

msItem.title: Expositio Ortulani super praedicta epistola, f. 3r

support.watermark: Several different designs, including one which appears to be a cardinal's hat but is too faint to read.

supportDesc.extent: 43 leaves : 213 x 155 (194 x 134) mm. bound to 222 x 150 mm
supportDesc.foliation: Paper, 43; 1-2¹⁶ 3-6¹ 7⁸(-1); [1-43]; modern foliation in pencil, upper right recto, irregular contemporary pagination/foliation in ink, upper right recto.

decoDesc.decoNote: Several ink drawings of chemical apparatus (f. 9v); many chemical and alchemical symbols throughout.

binding.p: 17th-century Italian pasteboards. Paper frayed at the edges. Some evidence of worm and rodent damage. Lower outer edge of upper cover and many front folios badly damaged, possibly resulting in some slight loss of text.

origin.p: Written in Italy between the late 16th and the early 17th century.
